Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: An Archaeological Survey for Substructure in the Stellar Halos of the Nearest Massive Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Our Milky Way galaxy is surrounded by "dwarf" galaxies that orbit and occasionally collide with our galaxy. We are part of a "local group" of large galaxies, each with its own swarm of dwarf galaxies. One of the important unanswered questions in astronomy is how these galaxies formed and how they change in time. Our current understanding of structure in the universe suggests that a large galaxy like the Milky Way should actually host a larger number of dwarf satellites than we observe. To examine whether this is universal or merely a property of our local group, this program will conduct a detailed census of the regions surrounding two of our nearest galactic neighbors. They will survey two types of galaxy - spiral, like the Milky Way, and a large elliptical galaxy - and then measure the basic properties of these newly discovered systems. This involves a collaborative effort between three institutions and will use some of the largest and best ground-based telescopes. All three PIs are active in education and public outreach. PI Sand's institution, Texas Tech University, has a new astrophysics research group and undergraduate concentration. The science in this proposal will help establish TTU's astrophysics program and reach out to the larger Lubbock community. In particular, two undergraduate astrophysics students will spend summers in California doing research for the program, allowing them to interact with the larger astrophysics community. PI Guhathakurta is very actively involved with several programs that provide mentoring and research experiences for high-school students.

The three PIs, along with a postdoctoral researcher and students, will address the observed lack of faint dwarf galaxies associated with the Milky Way and M31 (compared Lambda-CDM predictions for small-scale structure formation). Using the Magellan and Keck telescopes, they will conduct a panoramic imaging study to measure the stellar stream and dwarf galaxy content in NGC 253, a Milky Way-like spiral in a filamentary environment, and NGC 5128, a massive central elliptical galaxy. They will also use Keck+Diemos and newly-developed coaddition techniques to obtain spectra of tidal streams and dwarf galaxies. If successful, this would enable kinematic and metallicity studies for the first time outside the local group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the currently favored theory of cosmology, known as LambdaCDM, the universe consists primarily of dark energy (lambda) and cold dark matter.  Computer simulations of cosmic evolution premised on this theory show that large galaxies like the Milky Way should be surrounded by enormous numbers of smaller clumps of dark matter.  Hundreds of those clumps are massive enough that galaxies might be expected to have formed inside them.  In contrast, observations of the Milky Way's neighborhood had revealed less than 30 small galaxies orbiting the Milky Way at the time we began this project (the total is now up to about 55).  Thus, the Milky Way seems to contain many fewer satellites than the LambdaCDM model would have predicted.  This missing satellite problem has been the source of intense debates, centering on three possible solutions: (1) the LambdaCDM model is wrong, perhaps because dark matter does not clump as much as expected, (2) the predicted satellites are actually present, but because of the physics of galaxy formation many of them were unable to form stars and therefore remain invisible, or (3) the Milky Way happens to have an unusually small population of satellites.


At the outset of this project only the two nearest large galaxies, the Milky Way and M31, had been carefully searched for satellite galaxies containing a stellar mass of at least 100,000 solar masses.  The lack of comparable observations of other similar galaxies made it impossible to distinguish between the potential solutions to the missing satellite problem described above.  In order to test solution (3), we proposed to carry out wide-field imaging surveys around two of the next-closest large galaxies, NGC 253 and NGC 5128 (also known as Centaurus A).  NGC 253 is a spiral galaxy quite comparable to the Milky Way, while NGC 5128 is a somewhat more massive elliptical galaxy; both systems are located 11-12 million light years away from us.

Using the Megacam instrument on one of the Magellan 6.5 meter telescopes in Chile, we obtained deep imaging covering an area of ~15 square degrees surrounding each galaxy.  We then created maps of the distribution of red giant stars in the vicinity of each object.  By searching for groups of stars in these maps we discovered 11 new dwarf galaxies near Centaurus A and 4 near NGC 253.  We also identified a number of new streams, shells, and clouds of stars originating from dwarf galaxies that are being (or have been) destroyed by tidal forces in the outer regions of Centaurus A.  One of the new NGC 253 satellites is in the process of tidal disruption as well.  We obtained deeper imaging of seven of the Centaurus A dwarfs and the most prominent tidal stream with the Hubble Space Telescope, with which we confirmed their association with Centaurus A, measured their structural properties more accurately, and studied their ages and heavy element abundances.  We determined that the satellite population of Centaurus A matches that of the Milky Way.  This result demonstrates that the missing satellite problem is not limited to the Local Group and cannot be explained by assuming that the properties of the Milky Way's satellite galaxies are cosmically atypical.

In the second phase of this project we developed a new technique to obtain spectroscopy of distant, faint dwarf galaxies.  The individual stars in galaxies more than 10 million light years away are too faint for spectroscopy with current telescopes, but we showed that it is possible to combine the spectra of several dozen stars together in order to measure the velocity of the galaxy and its heavy element content.  So far we have successfully applied this technique to one of the NGC 253 dwarf galaxies we discovered and a dwarf galaxy orbiting the nearby spiral galaxy M81.  This work offers a preview of capabilities that will become routine when the next generation of giant ground-based telescopes is completed.

Two postdoctoral researchers (one at Carnegie Observatories and one at Texas Tech with frequent visits to Carnegie) received training as part of this project, and both have now advanced to tenure-track faculty positions.  Other broader impacts related to this project included outreach to elementary school students.
